text: so it seemed earlier this week like
negotiations over the fiscal cliff had
completely stalled out the White House
put out an offer for about 1.6 trillion
and new tax revenue over 10 years
Republicans put out an offer for about
800 billion in new tax revenue over 10
years without raising the top tax rates
both sides rejected the other offer and
it looks like we were at stalemate
that's not exactly right behind the
scenes it seems like more Republicans
are supporting raising taxes on the top
2% letting this you know 2% of tax cuts
expire and then fighting everything else
out next year and so what would be
keeping them from from not just letting
everything go next year and just you
know having the taxes hiked it's the
debt ceiling so at the end of this year
the country is going to reach its
statutory borrowing limit and towards
the end of februari or early march
Congress is going to have to raise it so
what's happening in Washington today
well one thing is that there are a
number of charities who have come down
to DC so groups like the American Cancer
Society in the united way to lobby in
the White House and in Congress to keep
a deduction for charitable contributions
it's one bipartisan way that folks have
talked about to raise tax revenue is to
limit deductions or exclusions and
charities are very worried that this
could end up hitting their finances
pretty badly i'm annie lowrey in
washington DC
